unnormalised: ## My Brush with Banking (and the Time My UPI Almost Broke)
normalised: my brush with banking and the time my U-P-I almost broke

unnormalised: Okay, folks, gather 'round. Let me tell you a story about a regular Tuesday that almost turned into a financial horror movie. It all started innocently enough. I needed to transfer ₹25,000 to my cousin, Priya, for her wedding lehenga. Easy peasy, right? Just a quick UPI transaction.
normalised: okay, folks, gather 'round. let me tell you a story about a regular Tuesday that almost turned into a financial horror movie. it all started innocently enough. i needed to transfer rupee twenty five thousand to my cousin, priya, for her wedding lehenga. easy peasy, right? just a quick U-P-I transaction.

unnormalised: Now, I'm generally pretty tech-savvy. I use my banking app, ICICI Bank, all the time. Pay bills, check my balance, the whole shebang. I even invested a small amount, like ₹5000, in mutual funds last year, thanks to my friend Rohan's constant nagging. So, I confidently opened the app, entered Priya’s UPI ID, and punched in the amount. Hit "send," and... nothing. Just that spinning wheel of doom.
normalised: now, i'm generally pretty tech-savvy. i use my banking app, I-C-I-C-I bank, all the time. pay bills, check my balance, the whole shebang. i even invested a small amount, like rupee five thousand, in mutual funds last year, thanks to my friend rohan's constant nagging. so, i confidently opened the app, entered priya’s U-P-I I-D, and punched in the amount. hit "send," and... nothing. just that spinning wheel of doom.

unnormalised: I waited, thinking it was probably just a network issue. You know how it is, especially during peak hours when everyone in Mumbai is probably ordering chai and paying for it with UPI. But after a solid 5 minutes, the transaction still hadn't gone through. I checked my balance – it hadn’t been deducted. But here's where I panicked: I got a message saying "Transaction failed - insufficient balance."
normalised: i waited, thinking it was probably just a network issue. you know how it is, especially during peak hours when everyone in mumbai is probably ordering chai and paying for it with U-P-I. but after a solid five minutes, the transaction still hadn't gone through. i checked my balance – it hadn’t been deducted. but here's where i panicked: i got a message saying "transaction failed - insufficient balance."

unnormalised: Huh? I knew I had more than ₹25,000 in my account. I’d literally checked it just before. Then, another message popped up: "Debit of ₹25000 successful. Balance: ₹2000." Wait, what? My brain short-circuited. Had the money gone through or not?
normalised: huh? i knew i had more than rupee twenty five thousand in my account. i’d literally checked it just before. then, another message popped up: "debit of rupee twenty five thousand successful. balance: rupee two thousand." wait, what? my brain short-circuited. had the money gone through or not?

unnormalised: I immediately called ICICI Bank's customer care. After navigating through approximately 7000 automated options (or so it felt), I finally got through to a real person. After verifying my details (name, address, DOB, mother’s maiden name, the usual), I explained the situation.
normalised: i immediately called I-C-I-C-I bank's customer care. after navigating through approximately seven thousand automated options or so it felt, i finally got through to a real person. after verifying my details name, address, D-O-B, mother’s maiden name, the usual, i explained the situation.

unnormalised: The customer service rep, a very patient lady named Ms. Sharma, checked my account activity. She confirmed that a transaction of ₹25000 had indeed gone through, but then been reversed due to a "technical glitch." Apparently, there was a temporary issue with the UPI server at around 14:30 IST that day.

unnormalised: "But," she added, "it seems another transaction for Rs. 25000 is showing as pending." My heart did a little somersault. Double debit? I envisioned myself living on instant noodles for the next month.
normalised: "but," she added, "it seems another transaction for rupees twenty five thousand is showing as pending." my heart did a little somersault. double debit? i envisioned myself living on instant noodles for the next month.

unnormalised: Ms. Sharma assured me that the pending transaction would likely be reversed within 24-48 hours. "Please wait till 18/06/2024, 14:30 for the refund to reflect," she advised. Easy for her to say!
normalised: M-S. sharma assured me that the pending transaction would likely be reversed within twenty four to forty eight hours. "please wait till eighteenth june two thousand and twenty four, fourteen thirty for the refund to reflect," she advised. easy for her to say!

unnormalised: I spent the rest of the day obsessively checking my account balance. Every time my phone pinged, I braced myself for the worst. Finally, the next morning, I saw it: a credit of ₹25000. Relief washed over me in a massive wave.
normalised: i spent the rest of the day obsessively checking my account balance. every time my phone pinged, i braced myself for the worst. finally, the next morning, i saw it: a credit of rupee twenty five thousand. relief washed over me in a massive wave.

unnormalised: The whole ordeal reminded me of a crucial lesson: always keep a record of your transactions, and don't hesitate to contact your bank if something seems off. Digital banking is convenient, but it's not without its quirks. And maybe, just maybe, I should diversify my payment methods a little. Next time, maybe I'll stick to good old cash or even a cheque! Learning from experience, one near-financial-meltdown at a time. Thank God for Ms. Sharma, UPI, and the eventual refund of my Rs. 25000. Now, Priya will get her lehenga, and I can breathe again.
